questions.question: Which of the following is a possible stress point in the day-to-day operations of the EMS system that would likely be identified by a comprehensive CQI program?
options: Increased emergency calls
Onboarding new staff
Personal finance issues
Receiving facility issues
questions.answer: Receiving facility issues

questions.question: Compared to an EMT, an AEMT:
options: can legally transfer patient care to a provider of lesser training.
can administer a variety of emergency medications.
has a more advanced knowledge of pathophysiology.
is trained and authorized to perform manual defibrillation.
questions.answer: has a more advanced knowledge of pathophysiology.

questions.question: In order to link research and evidence to patient care, one must:
options: ensure that the quality of the evidence is sufficient to justify changing patient care protocols.
recognize that evidence is less reliable than scientific data that produce sound statistics.
understand that only level 1 evidence can be used to justify changing patient care protocols.
conduct research at least every 10 years and then perform a retrospective analysis of the data.
questions.answer: ensure that the quality of the evidence is sufficient to justify changing patient care protocols.

questions.question: Upon arriving at the scene of a motorcycle crash, you are approached by an EMR. It is the responsibility of the EMR to provide which of the following information?
options: Initial scene and patient assessment findings and any basic care that was provided to the patient
His or her perception of the criticality of the patient's condition and suspicion for internal bleeding
How the crash occurred and approximately when he or she first arrived at the scene
The patient's medical history
questions.answer: Initial scene and patient assessment findings and any basic care that was provided to the patient

questions.question: When faced with a situation that is not addressed in your EMS system's protocols, you should:
options: let experience guide further care of the patient.
radio your medical director to obtain orders.
proceed with basic life support and transport.
contact the nurse at the receiving facility.
questions.answer: radio your medical director to obtain orders.

questions.question: Which of the following was a required component identified by the Emergency Medical Services System Act of 1973?
options: National EMS certification
Resource management
Mutual aid agreements
Trauma systems
questions.answer: Mutual aid agreements

questions.question: How should the paramedic decide which facility to transport a patient to?
options: Ask the patient where his or her physician is located.
Recognize the facilities that are near major streets and highways.
Choose the facility that is closest to the scene of the emergency.
Choose the facility that is most capable of caring for the patient's needs.
questions.answer: Choose the facility that is most capable of caring for the patient's needs.

questions.question: A patient has requested to be transported to a specific hospital; however, the hospital does not have the proper resources to meet the patient's needs. You should:
options: remember that the hospital can always transfer the patient to a more appropriate facility.
contact medical control and request permission to transport the patient to his or her choice. hospital.
determine if there is a more appropriate medical facility within a reasonable distance.
advise the patient that his or her hospital of choice is a poorly equipped medical facility.
questions.answer: determine if there is a more appropriate medical facility within a reasonable distance.

questions.question: The 2009 National EMS Education Standards:
options: require inclusion of a college-level pathophysiology course within the paramedic program.
outline the minimum knowledge base that the paramedic must possess in order to function in the field.
mandate that the paramedic designation must be achieved through an associate degree program.
clearly state that all paramedic training programs must be at least 1,200 hours in length.
questions.answer: outline the minimum knowledge base that the paramedic must possess in order to function in the field.

questions.question: A paramedic notices a tripping hazard in the home of a patient during an emergency call. What should the paramedic do?
options: Tell the patient or a family member that they must fix the tripping hazard before they transport the patient to the hospital
Talk about the findings with the patient or a family member
Fix the tripping hazard before attending to the patient
Recognize that it isn't the role of the paramedic to discuss topics unrelated to the emergency call
questions.answer: Talk about the findings with the patient or a family member

questions.question: Most of a patient's psychological stress responses to an illness or injury are:
options: predictable, so the paramedic can prepare for them.
not under his or her conscious control.
a direct result of the paramedic's presence.
related to the patient's level of maturity.
questions.answer: not under his or her conscious control.

questions.question: Upon arriving at the scene of a motor vehicle collision:
options: you should look for hazards as you approach the vehicle.
the ambulance should be parked at least 200 feet away.
traffic is usually the only hazard with which to be concerned.
parking the ambulance on the road may cause a fire.
questions.answer: you should look for hazards as you approach the vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding a patient's reaction to an illness or injury and his or her cultural background is correct?
options: You should touch the patient early in the assessment process to determine his or her cultural customs.
Refusal of a patient to maintain eye contact with you indicates an emotional indifference, not a cultural one.
You will not be able to manage patient care well if you do not respect the culture of your patient.
In most cultures, direct eye contact shows deference to the paramedic's authority and uniform.
questions.answer: You will not be able to manage patient care well if you do not respect the culture of your patient.

questions.question: When wearing gloves while taking care of a patient, you should:
options: avoid removing them until patient care has been completed.
ensure that the gloves are sterile before you touch the patient.
take them off before you drive the ambulance to the hospital.
routinely apply two pairs of gloves for added protection.
questions.answer: take them off before you drive the ambulance to the hospital.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding tuberculosis (TB) is correct?
options: It is one of the most common diseases contracted by breathing in germs.
The number of patients with TB has been declining over the last 5 years.
A surgical mask should be worn when caring for any patient with TB.
N95 respirators do not provide protection against TB as once thought.
questions.answer: It is one of the most common diseases contracted by breathing in germs.

questions.question: The first step in developing an injury prevention program is to:
options: establish goals and objectives.
conduct a community assessment.
plan and test interventions.
define the injury problem.
questions.answer: conduct a community assessment.

questions.question: A 77-year-old man with end-stage COPD and renal failure is found unresponsive by his daughter. Your assessment reveals that the patient is apneic and pulseless. The daughter presents you with an out-of-hospital DNR order; however, the document expired 3 months ago. You should:
options: confirm that the order has expired before initiating any patient treatment.
begin full resuscitative efforts because the DNR order is no longer valid.
realize that the patient cannot be resuscitated and notify the coroner.
begin CPR only and contact medical control for further guidance.
questions.answer: begin CPR only and contact medical control for further guidance.

questions.question: A 17-year-old woman presents with acute abdominal pain while at a party with her husband. You arrive at the scene, assess the patient, and advise her of the need for EMS treatment and transport. However, the patient, who is conscious and alert, refuses EMS treatment and transport and states that her husband will transport her in his car. You should:
options: accept her refusal because the fact that she is married makes her emancipated.
advise her of the potential risks of refusing EMS treatment and transport.
begin treatment using implied consent, because she is under 18 years of age.
ensure that she has decision-making capacity and then obtain a signed refusal.
questions.answer: advise her of the potential risks of refusing EMS treatment and transport.

questions.question: Which of the following scenarios reflects a violation of EMTALA?
options: Paramedics transport a woman in labor to the closest hospital
A hospital transfers an unstable patient to another facility
An emergency department provides stabilization care only
A registration clerk asks you if the patient has insurance
questions.answer: A hospital transfers an unstable patient to another facility

questions.question: A 39-year-old man with severe dehydration requires IV fluid therapy to treat his condition. The patient is conscious, alert, and oriented to person, place, time, and event. You should:
options: tell the patient that you are going to start an IV on him in order to replenish his body with lost fluid and electrolytes.
start the IV to quickly restore his body fluid balance and then explain to the patient why you started the IV line.
establish the IV line based on the law of implied consent, because his condition has impaired his decision-making capacity.
ask him if you can start an IV and explain the reason for the IV as well as the potential risks of IV therapy.
questions.answer: ask him if you can start an IV and explain the reason for the IV as well as the potential risks of IV therapy.
